thread.title: Marks & Spencer reduces the price of children's clothing to the rival retailers
thread.title_full: Marks & Spencer reduces the price of children's clothing to the rival retailers

author: Elijah
title: Marks & Spencer reduces the price of children's clothing to the rival retailers
text:
By Daily Mail City & Finance Reporter
Updated: 22:01 GMT, January 30, 2025
Marks & Spencer is reducing the price of children’s clothing when children’s clothes become its next battlefield to earn market share.
He hopes to attract more families as part of the impulse of response that has raised him from the crisis.
Under the rebirth of Chief Stuart Machin, it aims
Up to 20 percent in more than 100 products from its ‘Everyday Essentials’ range.
This includes a hoodie of £ 10 for very young children and £ 13 tracksuit for those between six and 16 years.
Alexandra Dimitriu, children’s director, said: ‘Customers seek reliable value.
Price war: Marks & Spencer bosses hope to attract even more family buyers by reducing the price of children’s clothing
‘When it comes to clothes, we know that Value is more than the price of the product: they also want the confidence that it is done well and is done to last and offers versatility. We have focused on investing on price and quality.
In August, M&S launched his first ‘Baby Club’, with discounts of up to £ 250 per year to attract the young family market.
This offers members of their discounts from the Sparks loyalty program to help the expectants and new parents.
Marks sold in M&S include breasts & potatoes, Pampers, Piccolo Baby Food and Bloom & Blossom.
In October, JP Morgan said the children were ‘low fruits’ for the retailer, who has already revived his fortune with great progress in food and women’s clothing.
M&S has 7 percent of the children’s clothing market, while the next one is 14 percent.
